title: Promotion code can be used more than redemption limit.

profile.name: Stripe
profile.about: Stripe is a technology company that builds economic infrastructure for the internet.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
While creating a promotion code a user can specify number of times that code can be redeemed.(i.e. Redemption limit)
{F1962666}
Codes aren't supposed to be redeemed more than the redemption limit.
But there exists a race condition that allows use of promotion codes more than redemption limit.
{F1962665}

## Steps To Reproduce:
[In these steps i have used just a browser to show how easy this is to exploit and even a person with very limited knowledge on technology can exploit this. This can certainly be scaled using burp and other software .]

1. As a merchant create a promotion code with Redemption limit 1.
{F1962664}
2. As a user, Visit any two payment links of same merchant with the coupon.
3. In both payment links, Fill the form and apply coupon but don't hit Pay/ Subscribe.
4.Hit both link's pay/subscribe button as fast as you can.
5. Both payment will be successful using one coupon two times.

## Supporting Material/References:
I have added a video poc.
In this poc, I have used a promotion code with redemption limit 2.
I have also used laptops screentouch feature to click both link's pay/subscribe button as fast as I could.
{F1962525}

## Impact

Promotion code can be used more than redemption limit.

activities.message:
Hey @d_sharad,

Thank you for your report!

After review, there doesn’t seem to be any security risk and/or security impact as a result of the behavior you are describing.

This appears to be more of a UX issue than a security risk.  The merchant can always remove the 2nd order from their end.

As a result, we will be closing this report as informative. If you are able to leverage this into a practical exploitation scenario, we will be happy to reevaluate this report.

This will not have any impact on your Signal or Reputation score. We appreciate your effort and look forward to seeing more reports from you in the future.

Kind regards,
@h1_analyst_ivan

Hello @h1_analyst_ivan ,
I am so sorry. My above explanation to the issue really feels like UX issue. Below I have tried to explain this issue as clearly as possible.

#Summary
While creating a coupon, a merchant can specify how many times a coupon can be used which is also called redemption limit. For eg: If redemption limit is set to 1, coupon can only be redeemed once. But this can be bypassed and coupon with redemption limit 1 can be used multiple times.

# Steps to reproduce
(for simplicity, i am dividing steps into two parts partA and partB)
Parameters needed:
**Promotion code**: (use unused promotion code with redmption limit 1)
**key**: (every merchant have a specific key in format pk_test_xxxxx)
{
    To get key parameter
    steps:
    1.Visit Payment link
    2. Apply any  coupon
    3. intercept the request.
    {F1964045}
}
**payment link**: (every payment link is in the form https://buy.stripe.com/test_xxxxxxx, we only use last part i.e test_xxxxxx)

#Part A
( In this part, we focus on obtaining large amount of session_id and payment_id )
1. Send get request to buy.stripe.com with payment link to obtain plink in Location header of response.(only plink is stripped from location header)
{F1963891}
2.This plink parameter is used with key to obtain session_id by sending Post request to ``` /v1/payment_pages/for_plink ```
{F1963892}
3.POST request is sent to ``` /v1/payment_pages/<session_id>``` with token to apply coupon in session.
(This can be done for multiple sessions since payment isn't done yet)
{F1963900}
4. One time payment_method is created using card credentials and user details by sending post request to ```/v1/payment_methods```
{F1963903}
5.Steps 1 to 4 are done for large number of times and session_id and payment_mrthod for each iteration is stored.

#Part B
(In this part, we use session _id and payment_method are used to send concurrent request to server)

6. To complete the process a POST request is sent to ```/v1/payment_pages/<session_id>/confirm ``` with key, payment_method, expected_amount and so on.
(**Here expected_amount is amount after discount)
{F1963913} 
**This step is performed concurrently for all iteration of session _id and payment_method**
7. you can see 200 ok responses which confirms use of coupon more than redemption limit. This can be  confirmed by viewing coupon details on ```dashboard.stripe.com ```
{F1963952}

Hello @h1_analyst_ivan ,

Any Updates??

Thanks
@d_sharad
Hi @d_sharad - I'm discussing this submission internally with the Stripe team. You will be updated as soon as there is additional information to share. Thanks for your patience!

Hello @h1_analyst_ivan ,

I am sorry to disturb you but my patience is wearing out. It has already exceeded the programs average time to triage. Is there any problem??
I'd love your response.

Kind Regards,
@d_sharad

Based on your initial description, there do not appear to be any security implications as a direct result of this behavior. If you disagree, please reply with additional information describing your reasoning. Including a working proof-of-concept can be incredibly helpful in our assessment of these claims.

Hi @d_sharad,

While I can see that the promotion code is exceeding the redemption limit, the merchant can easily cancel the multiple orders that shouldn't have had the promotion applied. As such, the impact is quite low. We may make changes in the future to make this a more robust check, but as of now, we are not planning to make a change here.

Thanks,
@meditatingllama

Hi @meditatingllama,
As you can see below , I was able to redeem the coupon for 25 times. I was able to perform this upto 32 times. It would be quite difficult for merchant to cancel all the orders.
{F1963952}

https://hackerone.com/reports/1328278
In contrast, the merchant can easily cancel the order made using archieved price in the above report yet it is accepted.

What you have here is a classic case of Race Condition. Some of previously known cases are:
https://hackerone.com/reports/59179
https://hackerone.com/reports/157996

thanks,
@d_sharad

Hi @meditatingllama ,
As you claimed, Merchants can cancel the orders. For them to cancel, they should be well known about this vulnerability. 

If you are unwilling to disclose this report, I am more than happy to report this to all your major clients to make them aware of this vulnerability.

That's all.

Hi @d_sharad,

Thank you for following up and providing the additional information. When we closed this as Informative, we did so thinking the race condition could be used for a small number of additional redemptions. Based on your proof of concept with 25 redemptions, we will take another look at this report to confirm there isn't a broader underlying issue.

That said, the status of this report still may not change. In the event it does, we continue to believe that the impact is limited because the race condition can't be triggered more than once for a specific promotion code. In other words, if you trigger the race condition once, you won't be able to trigger it again for that same promotion code. This is materially different from the ability to repeatedly make a purchase with an archived price as in the report that you linked.

Lastly, we are sorry that the experience on this report may have not met your expectations. However, with regards to your suggestion about contacting Stripe customers, our program terms states the following:

“By participating in this program, you agree not to publicly or privately disclose the contents of your submission, your findings, your communications with Stripe related to your participation in the Program, or any facts you have learned about Stripe in the course of your participation in the Program to any third parties without Stripe's prior written approval. There are no exceptions.”

Our policy also makes it clear that whether we decide to reward a bug report is entirely up to our discretion. 

If you violate our program terms, you would be removed from eligible participation in our bug bounty program and we would be required to notify HackerOne as to why we made that decision. We are focused on building long term relationships with hackers and want to see your continued success. If you have any questions about this, please feel free to ask.

Thanks,
@meditatingllama

Hi @meditatingllama ,
I am sorry for my above response. I respect all policies and will follow them.

Not just 25 times, I was able to perform this upto 32 times.

I was also able to buy not just one type but multiple types of products with coupon.

The time difference is so significant I was able to exploit just by clicking pay button simultaneously at browser.
{F1962525}
Person without any knowledge of race condition can exploit this.

Race conditions included below could only be trigerred once too.
https://hackerone.com/reports/59179
https://hackerone.com/reports/157996

I understand @stripe is unwilling to solve this. But Isn't it @stripe 's duty to inform its users about this issue?

Finally,
Once again I am asking for disclosure.

Thanks,
@d_sharad

Hi @d_sharad,

We will not be disclosing this report at this time while we take another look at this report to ensure that there is not a deeper underlying issue.

Thanks,
@meditatingllama

Hello @meditatingllama ,

Any Upates??

Regards,
@d_sharad

Hey @d_sharad,

The team is still looking into this. I have reached out for an update.

Thank you for your patience.

@h1_analyst_ivan

Thanks again for your report.

I’m pleased to inform you that your report is eligible for our vulnerability reward program, and so we’d like to offer you a reward. Congratulations!

We appreciate your time and effort in submitting this report! Please take this time to re-review [Stripe’s program terms and conditions](https://hackerone.com/stripe?type=team#user-content-terms-and-conditions) and we hope to hear from you if you discover any issues within the scope of [our bug bounty program](https://hackerone.com/stripe)!
Given the severity of this issue and its impact, it may take some time for us to fix the described issue.

Hello @snoringllama ,

Thankyou for the bounty.
I hope the issue will be fixed as soon as possible.

Happy Tihar.
Thanks ,
@d_sharad

Hi @snoringllama,
I was just wondering if i could get ETA for the fix.
Thank you for your time,
@d_sharad

Hey @d_sharad,

The team is still looking into this. I have reached out for an update.

Thank you for your patience.

@h1_analyst_ivan

Hey @h1_analyst_ivan ,

I forgot to mention in previous comments i had also found multiple products could also be purchased.
i.e. instead of buying one product multipe times malicious actor could also purchase multiple products with one time promotion coupon.

Please keep the team updated in this too.
Thanks
@d_sharad

Hey @d_sharad,

Thank you.

We should have an update for you soon.

@h1_analyst_ivan

Hey @d_sharad,

The internal team is still addressing this issue.

We hope to have an update for you soon.

Thank you!

@h1_analyst_ivan

The fix works. I wasn't able to reproduce the issue.
I checked for race condition, but after first redemption i got Response 400 whoch looks like :
```
HTTP/2 400 Bad Request
Server: nginx
Date: Thu, 17 Nov 2022 03:38:05 GMT
Content-Type: application/json
Content-Length: 255
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: GET, POST, HEAD, OPTIONS, DELETE
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://checkout.stripe.com
Access-Control-Expose-Headers: Request-Id, Stripe-Manage-Version, X-Stripe-External-Auth-Required, X-Stripe-Privileged-Session-Required
Access-Control-Max-Age: 300
Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store
Idempotency-Key: e8118277-5dd2-46d2-87ba-2e887f1a5486
Original-Request: req_LHyvhg42ZHybKA
Request-Id: req_LHyvhg42ZHybKA
Stripe-Should-Retry: false

{
  "error": {
    "code": "unredeemable_promotion_code",
    "message": "This promotion code cannot be redeemed.",
    "request_log_url": "https://dashboard.stripe.com/test/logs/req_LHyvhg42ZHybKA?t=1668656285",
    "type": "invalid_request_error"
  }
}
```
The python script which i provided earlier also fails to do the job.
{F2036440}

In short, The fix works.

Hey @snoringllama ,
Can we disclose this report?
Thanks.
@d_sharad

Before we begin the disclosure process, we’d like to provide you information about our process.

Per [our program terms](https://hackerone.com/stripe?type=team#user-content-terms-and-conditions), we ask that you limit disclosure to only the contents to be inserted into the public HackerOne report. Also, please be aware that either party may revoke or decline the disclosure request at any time.

Before disclosing the report via HackerOne, we would like to:

1. Verify report metadata (report title, severity, weakness, etc).
2. Provide a summary of the report if the issue is considered high or critical severity after metadata is verified.

High and critical severity issues will receive a limited disclosure while medium and lower severity issues will be fully disclosed. For the report metadata, we will make adjustments at our discretion but please let us know if you have any concerns about our adjustments.

If you have any follow up comments after disclosure about this report, please open another report on HackerOne with “Disclosure Followup” in the title.

Please let us know if this sounds good to you and we can proceed with the next steps!
